question.title: Compilation error in Maven/Java8 build: Cannot find symbol JSObject.getWindow

node.contents: I've the same issue like here Not able to resolve JSObject in a java applet project :

astNode.text: I've the same issue like here Not able to resolve JSObject in a java applet project :

node.contents: • JSObject is taken from the jfxrt.jar (JavaFX) inside the jdk instead from the plugin.jar, so there is no JSObject.getWindow method and compilation fails.

astNode.text: • JSObject is taken from the jfxrt.jar (JavaFX) inside the jdk instead from the plugin.jar, so there is no JSObject.getWindow method and compilation fails.

node.contents: Problem here is that I've a build with java 8 and maven so I can't remove jfxrt.jar from the build path and it seems that the order of JDK and maven dependencies can't be changed.

astNode.text: Problem here is that I've a build with java 8 and maven so I can't remove jfxrt.jar from the build path and it seems that the order of JDK and maven dependencies can't be changed.

node.contents: So is there a way to exclude JavaFX somehow or is there an alternative to JSObject.getWindow to call some JavaScript from the hosting website?

astNode.text: So is there a way to exclude JavaFX somehow or is there an alternative to JSObject.getWindow to call some JavaScript from the hosting website?

node.contents:
• The java compiler has an option "endorseddirs" to overwrite the bootstrap classes
  • If you place the plugin.jar inside one of these folders it overwrites the JSObject from JavaFX
  • In your maven poms you have to tell the compiler plugin which folders to search and you can use the dependency plugin to copy dependencies/artifacts to that folders

astNode.text:
• The java compiler has an option "endorseddirs" to overwrite the bootstrap classes
  • If you place the plugin.jar inside one of these folders it overwrites the JSObject from JavaFX
  • In your maven poms you have to tell the compiler plugin which folders to search and you can use the dependency plugin to copy dependencies/artifacts to that folders

node.contents: (If you have the plugin.jar as a maven dependency:)

astNode.text: (If you have the plugin.jar as a maven dependency:)

node.contents: Another option, which worked for me, is to include plugin.jar and call getWindow by reflection.

astNode.text: Another option, which worked for me, is to include plugin.jar and call getWindow by reflection.

node.contents: public JSObject getJSObject() { try { Method m = JSObject.class.getMethod("getWindow", Applet.class); return (JSObject)m.invoke(null, Applet.this); } catch (Exception e) { // do something return null; } }

astNode.text: public JSObject getJSObject() { try { Method m = JSObject.class.getMethod("getWindow", Applet.class); return (JSObject)m.invoke(null, Applet.this); } catch (Exception e) { // do something return null; } }

node.contents: Changing the order of dependencies isn't required.

astNode.text: Changing the order of dependencies isn't required.

node.contents: EDIT: It was working when running in Eclipse but had a NoSuchMethodException when running in the browser.

astNode.text: EDIT: It was working when running in Eclipse but had a NoSuchMethodException when running in the browser.

node.contents: Include plugin.jar, don't change the order. Then, include this method in a class.

astNode.text: Include plugin.jar, don't change the order. Then, include this method in a class.

elements.contents: public static JSObject getWindow(Applet applet) { if (applet != null) { AppletContext context = applet.getAppletContext(); if (context instanceof JSContext) { JSContext jsContext = (JSContext)context; JSObject jsObject = jsContext.getJSObject(); if (jsObject != null) { return jsObject; } } } throw new JSException(); }

units.rawText: public static JSObject getWindow(Applet applet) { if (applet != null) { AppletContext context = applet.getAppletContext(); if (context instanceof JSContext) { JSContext jsContext = (JSContext)context; JSObject jsObject = jsContext.getJSObject(); if (jsObject != null) { return jsObject; } } } throw new JSException(); }
